tit.cmt: 個人名・機関名など固有名詞は用語共通リストに従っています。 ＊セル49以降の作品名は' '内に入れましたが、D列右端が切れて画面に現れません。入力はしているので、ご確認ください。

sen.j: 梅原 龍三郎（うめはら りゅうざぶろう、1888年（明治21年）3月9日 - 1986年（昭和61年）1月16日）は、大正から昭和にかけての洋画家である。
sen.e: Ryuzaburo UMEHARA (梅原 龍三郎: March 9, 1888 - January 16, 1986) is an oil painter who was active from the Taisho Period to Showa Period.
Ryuzaburo UMEHARA (梅原 龍三郎: March 9, 1888 - January 16, 1986) is an oil painter who was active from the Taisho Period to Showa Period.
Ryuzaburo UMEHARA (梅原 龍三郎: March 9, 1888 - January 16, 1986) is an oil painter who was active from the Taisho Period to Showa Period.

sen.j: 京都府京都市下京区の生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Shimogyo-ku Word, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
He was born in Shimogyo-ku Word, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
He was born in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 左利き。
sen.e: He was a left-handed painter.
He was a left-handed painter.
He was a left-handed painter.

sen.j: 1914年（大正3年）までは名を良三郎と名乗るが、この名を本名とする説と、出生時に龍三郎と名付けられたが良三郎に改名していたとする説がある。
sen.e: Until 1914, he gave himself by the first name of Ryozaburo (良三郎), and there a theory that this is the real name, while the other say that he changed his name to Ryozaburo at some stage although he was named Ryuzaburo when he was born.

Until 1914, he gave himself the first name of Ryozaburo (良三郎), and there a theory that this is his real name, while another says that he changed his name to Ryozaburo at some stage although he was named Ryuzaburo when he was born.

Until 1914, he gave himself the first name of Ryozaburo (良三郎), and there a theory that this is his real name, while another says that he changed his name to Ryozaburo at some stage although he was named Ryuzaburo when he was born.

sen.j: 画風は華やかな色と豪快なタッチが特徴とされ、自由奔放と評される。
sen.e: His pictures were characterized with cheerful colors and a strong touch, and described as free and uninhibited.
His pictures were characterized with cheerful colors and a strong touch, and described as free and uninhibited.
His pictures were characterized with cheerful colors and a strong touch, and described as free and uninhibited.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦前から昭和の末期まで長年にわたって日本洋画界の重鎮として君臨した。
sen.e: Before the World War II to the end of the Showa Period he dominated the Japanese western-style painting society as a leading figure.
Before the World War II to the end of the Showa Period he dominated the Japanese western-style painting society as a leading figure.
Before World War II to the end of the Showa Period, he dominated the Japanese western-style painting society as a leading figure.
sen.cmt: Before the World War II to the end of the Showa Period →Before World War II to the end of the Showa Period,

sen.j: 晩年に使用した吉田五十八設計の東京都市ヶ谷のアトリエが山梨県北杜市の清春芸術村に移築され公開されている。
sen.e: His atelier (studio) at Ichigaya, Tokyo prefecture, designed by Isoya YOSHIDA, which he used in his later years, was moved to Kiyoharu art colony in Hokuto City, Yamanashi Prefecture and is now opened to the public.

His atelier (studio) at Ichigaya, Tokyo prefecture, designed by Isoya YOSHIDA, which he used in his later years, was moved to Kiyoharu art colony in Hokuto City, Yamanashi Prefecture and is now open to the public.

His atelier (studio) at Ichigaya, Tokyo prefecture, designed by Isoya YOSHIDA, which he used in his later years, was moved to Kiyoharu art colony in Hokuto City, Yamanashi Prefecture and is now open to the public.

sen.j: 京都府京都市下京区に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Shimogyo-ku Word, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
He was born in Shimogyo-ku Word, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
He was born in Shimogyo-ku Word, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 生家は染物問屋であった。
sen.e: His family was running a dye wholesale business.
His family ran a dye wholesale business.
His family ran a dye wholesale business.

sen.j: 京都府立第二中学校（現在の京都府立鳥羽高等学校）を中退し、伊藤快彦に絵を学んだ後、浅井忠が主催する聖護院洋画研究所（現在の関西美術院）に入る。
sen.e: He quitted the Kyoto Prefectural Daini High School (present Toba Senior High School, Kyoto Prefectural) and after learning the painting under Yoshihiko ITO, he entered Shogoin Institute of Western Art (present Kansai Bijutsuin (Fine Arts Academy of Western Japan))presided by Tadashi ASAI.

He quit the Kyoto Prefectural Daini High School (present Toba Senior High School, Kyoto Prefectural) and after learning painting under Yoshihiko ITO, he entered Shogoin Institute of Western Art (present Kansai Bijutsuin (Fine Arts Academy of Western Japan))presided by Tadashi ASAI.

He quit the Kyoto Prefectural Daini High School (present Toba Senior High School, Kyoto Prefectural) and after learning painting under Yoshihiko ITO, he entered Shogoin Institute of Western Art (present Kansai Bijutsuin (Fine Arts Academy of Western Japan))presided by Tadashi ASAI.

sen.j: 同時期に安井曾太郎も学んでいた。
sen.e: At the same period, Sotaro YASUI was also learning there.
At the same period, Sotaro YASUI also learned there.
At the same period, Sotaro YASUI also learned there.

sen.j: 1908年（明治41年）に田中喜作（後に美術史家となる）と共にフランスに留学。
sen.e: In 1908, he went to France to learn the paintings with Kisaku TANAKA (later he became an art historian).
In 1908, he went to France to learn about paintings with Kisaku TANAKA (later he became an art historian).
In 1908, he went to France to learn about paintings with Kisaku TANAKA (later he became an art historian).

sen.j: パリに滞在しアカデミー・ジュリアンに通った。
sen.e: While his stayed in Paris, he went to Academie Julian.
While he stayed in Paris, he went to Academie Julian.
While he stayed in Paris, he went to Academie Julian.

sen.j: 1909年（明治42年）にピエール＝オーギュスト・ルノワールの指導を受ける機会を得た。
sen.e: 1909, he acquired the opportunity to receive the guidance of Pierre-Auguste RENOIR.
1909, he acquired the opportunity to receive guidance from Pierre-Auguste RENOIR.
1909, he acquired the opportunity to receive guidance from Pierre-Auguste RENOIR.

sen.j: 知人の有島生馬を通じて、1910年（明治43年）にはルノワールについてや、パリの芸術について、雑誌『白樺 (雑誌)』に寄稿している。
sen.e: In 1910, he contributed the articles on RENOIR and the art in Paris to a journal "Shirakaba," through the channel of his acquaintance, Ikuma ARISHIMA.
In 1910, he contributed articles on RENOIR and the art in Paris to a journal "Shirakaba," through his acquaintance, Ikuma ARISHIMA.
In 1910, he contributed articles on RENOIR and the art in Paris to a journal "Shirakaba," through his acquaintance, Ikuma ARISHIMA.

sen.j: 1913年（大正2年）に帰国し、東京神田で個展「梅原良三郎油絵展覧会」を白樺社の主催で開催。
sen.e: In 1913, he returned to Japan, and held an exhibition of his own works 'The Exhibition of Oil Paintings of Ryozaburo UMEHARA' sponsored by a publishing firm Shirakaba-sha at Kanda, Tokyo
In 1913, he returned to Japan, and held an exhibition of his own works 'The Exhibition of Oil Paintings of Ryozaburo UMEHARA' sponsored by a publishing firm Shirakaba-sha at Kanda, Tokyo
In 1913, he returned to Japan, and held an exhibition of his own works 'The Exhibition of Oil Paintings of Ryozaburo UMEHARA' sponsored by a publishing firm Shirakaba-sha at Kanda, Tokyo

sen.j: この際に白樺社同人の武者小路実篤、志賀直哉、柳宗悦との知遇を得た。
sen.e: At that time he had come to know Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Naoya SHIGA, and Soetsu YANAGI, who were associates of Shirakaba-sha
At that time he came to know Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Naoya SHIGA, and Soetsu YANAGI, who were associates of Shirakaba-sha
At that time he came to know Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Naoya SHIGA, and Soetsu YANAGI, who were associates of Shirakaba-sha

sen.j: その後1914年（大正3年）の二科会の設立に関わる。
sen.e: After that, in 1914, he was involved in the establishment of the Nika Association.
After that, in 1914, he became involved in the establishment of the Nika Association.
After that, in 1914, he became involved in the establishment of the Nika Association.

sen.j: 同年結婚し長女と長男が生まれた。
sen.e: In the same year, he got married, and the first daughter and son were born.
In the same year, he was married, and his first daughter and son were born.
In the same year, he was married, and his first daughter and son were born.

sen.j: 1920年（大正9年）に再び渡仏するが、前年に死去したルノアールの弔問のためでもあったという。
sen.e: In 1920, he again went to France, and it is said that this visit was to make a condolatory call to RENOIR who died the previous year.
In 1920, he again went to France, and it is said that this visit was to make a condolatory call to RENOIR who died the previous year.
In 1920, he again went to France, and it is said that this visit was to make a condolatory call to RENOIR who died the previous year.

sen.j: 1922年（大正11年）に春陽会の設立に参加。
sen.e: In 1922, he participated to establish the Shunyo-kai Art Society.
In 1922, he participated to establish the Shunyo-kai Art Society.
In 1922, he participated to establish the Shunyo-kai Art Society.

sen.j: その後、春陽会を去り、1925年（大正14年）に土田麦僊の招きで国画創作協会に合流し、国画創作協会洋画部（第2部と称した）を設置した。
sen.e: After that, he left the Shunyo-kai and joinedKokuga Sosaku Kyokai (National Creative Painting Association) in 1925 with the invitation of Bakusen TSUCHIDA and set up the department of western-style painting (called The second Department) within the Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai.

After that, he left the Shunyo-kai and joinedKokuga Sosaku Kyokai (National Creative Painting Association) in 1925 with the invitation of Bakusen TSUCHIDA and set up the department of western-style painting (called The second Department) within the Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai.

After that, he left the Shunyo-kai and joined Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai (National Creative Painting Association) with the invitation of Bakusen TSUCHIDA and set up the department of western-style painting (called The 2nd Department) within the Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai.
sen.cmt: joinedKokuga Sosaku Kyokai →joined Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）に国画創作協会が解散した際に、洋画部が独立し「国画会」となった。
sen.e: In 1928, when Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai was dissolved, the department of western-style painting became independent and formed 'Kokugakai' (Society for National Painting).
In 1928, when Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai was dissolved, the department of western-style painting became independent and formed 'Kokugakai' (Society for National Painting).
In 1928, when Kokuga Sosaku Kyokai was dissolved, the department of western-style painting became independent and formed 'Kokugakai' (Society for National Painting).

sen.j: 1935年（昭和10年）に帝国美術院（現在の日本芸術院）会員となる。
sen.e: In 1935, he became a member of the Imperial Art Academy (present Japan Art Academy)
In 1935, he became a member of the Imperial Art Academy (present Japan Art Academy)
In 1935, he became a member of the Imperial Art Academy (present Japan Art Academy)

sen.j: 1944年（昭和19年）には帝室技芸員、東京美術学校（現在の東京芸術大学）教授となる。
sen.e: In 1944, he became a Teishitsu Gigeiin (Imperial art expert), as well as, a professor at Tokyo Fine Art School(present Tokyo University of Art).
In 1944, he became a Teishitsu Gigeiin (Imperial art expert), as well as, a professor at the Tokyo Fine Art School(present Tokyo University of Art).
In 1944, he became a Teishitsu Gigeiin (Imperial art expert), as well as, a professor at the Tokyo Fine Art School(present Tokyo University of Art).

sen.j: 1952年（昭和27年）に東京芸術大学教授を辞任し、渡欧しベネチア・ビエンナーレの国際審査員を務めた。
sen.e: In 1952, he resigned his position as a professor at Tokyo University of Art, and went to Europe to act as an international judge in Venezia-Biennale.
In 1952, he resigned his position as a professor at the Tokyo University of Art, and went to Europe to act as an international judge in Venezia-Biennale.
In 1952, he resigned his position as a professor at the Tokyo University of Art, and went to Europe to act as an international judge in Venezia-Biennale.

sen.j: 同年に文化勲章を受章。
sen.e: In the same year, he was awarded an Order of Cultural Merit.
In the same year, he was awarded an Order of Cultural Merit.
In the same year, he was awarded an Order of Cultural Merit.

sen.j: 1953年（昭和28年）に軽井沢にアトリエを設けた。
sen.e: In 1953, he set up his atelier (studio) at Karuizawa.
In 1953, he set up his atelier (studio) at Karuizawa.
In 1953, he set up his atelier (studio) at Karuizawa.

sen.j: 1957年（昭和32年）に日本芸術院会員を辞任。
sen.e: In 1957, he resigned the position as a member of the Japan Art Academy.
In 1957, he resigned his position as a member of the Japan Art Academy.
In 1957, he resigned his position as a member of the Japan Art Academy.

sen.j: 「横臥裸婦」（1908年、、愛知県美術館蔵）
sen.e: Reclining Nude' (1908, owned by Aichi Prefectural Museum)
